8.30.17  7:49 am   Have you ever been asked "what kind of music" you do? I'm sure you've been asked this on this page, but what about irl? I play in a band, and whenever anyone asks me what type of music we play, I never know how to anwer. In fact, I think most musicians won't give you a straight answer to that question. What's your go-to response for this? I usually just answer "we play a bunch of stuff" or something like that.

8.29.17  9:35 pm   I am looking at a piece of sheet music and it has 2 sets of quintuplet 16th notes, and a set of sextuplet 16th notes, all noted together as a triplet.. like there's 2 sets of 5 sixteenth notes with the little bracket and a 5 over each group, and then six sixteenth notes with a little bracket and a 6, and then over all 3 groups there's one long bracket with a 3... what is this mean? Ive never seen a tuplet inside of a tuplet before... How am I supposed to play that?

8.29.17  9:08 pm   You ever get to point in writing a song where it starts to feel like the song is writing itself?

      Like it becomes almost obvious where the melody "wants" to go/what the next chord will be?

     What I'm wondering is, should I let this happen? Like if the melody is just screaming out that it wants to go here, should I say "no, fuck you, you're going there instead!"

8.29.17  7:04 pm   Hi, I was the one who asked about Ryland by Julian Lage (on World's Fair). There are really quiet notes in the first and second measures of the song (if you are thinking of it in 6/8) starting on the sixth 8th note that goes A D A D A. And the next time it happens is on the down beat of the 4th measure and the notes are G E G E. There are other times it happens with different notes too. My first guess was that they were harmonics because some of them seem out of tune but I can't figure it out.

8.29.17  4:54 pm   do you sometimes think that you fit (or at least can survive) in everywhere but you belong to nowhere and you will never find your home? i do and i feel like i have to be nothing so i can be everything and i have to be nobody so i can be everybody. i thought it was what makes me write and how i became my characters and stories themselves. i became all of them, even the ones i didn't write yet. i split myself, one piece for one possibility but i can't start to do something because i am scared. there is a sea of possibilities between me and the future. like you said, i am drowning in infinity and i am broken into a thousand pieces, at the same point i was before. is this why i can't encourage myself to write again? do i have to be whole? and if yes, how can i become one again?

8.29.17  2:08 pm   A lot of times when I'm writing a song, I go through all these chord changes and have a melody line all the way from the beginning to end of the verse (or chorus), but then I'll get stuck as to how to get back 'home', like get back to the beginning of the next verse. Some songs the verse or chorus ends on a melody note/chord where I can just go straight back home without any sort of transition or anything like that... but sometimes the last note/chord wouldn't transition right going straight into the next verse. Does this ever happen to you? Any tips? It's like a puzzle, I see the chord or note I'm on, see where I need to go, but then I have to find something to bridge the gap between.
